symptoms: Erosions and ulcers in oral cavity
cattle_diseases.transmission: Contact with asymptomatic carrier sheep or wildebeest
healing_process: Rarely recover - typically fatal
Disease course of 3-7 days in acute form
prevention: Separation of cattle from sheep and wildebeest
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor; usually fatal

symptoms: Neurological signs in calves (incoordination/ataxia, hindlimb paralysis/weakness)
Most adult cattle show no clinical signs
cattle_diseases.transmission: Transplacental, ingestion of oocysts from dog feces
healing_process: Not applicable - infected animals remain carriers
prevention: Control of dog access to cattle areas
Testing and culling of seropositive animals
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor for preventing future abortions in infected cows

symptoms: Characteristic "ping" sound on percussion of left flank (LDA) or right flank (RDA)
treatments: Surgical correction (right flank omentopexy, toggle pin, etc.)
Correction of fluid and electrolyte imbalances
healing_process: Improvement within 24-48 hours post-surgery
Return to normal appetite in 3-5 days
Complete recovery in 7-14 days
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with surgical correction; guarded without intervention

symptoms: Various forms: filamentous, flat, or nodular
Common locations: head, neck, shoulders, teats
Large warts may ulcerate and bleed
Can interfere with function (e.g., teat warts affecting milking)
cattle_diseases.transmission: Direct contact, contaminated equipment, trauma to skin
healing_process: Spontaneous regression in 6-12 months as immunity develops
Rapid healing after surgical removal
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Excellent; rarely a significant health issue

cattle_diseases.alternative_names: White line abscess, White line separation
cattle_diseases.causative_agents: Mechanical separation with secondary bacterial infection
symptoms: Separation of white line with impacted debris
Discharge of pus at coronary band in severe cases
healing_process: Initial improvement within 24-48 hours after drainage
Complete healing in 2-4 weeks
Regular follow-up trimming needed
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; guarded if infection reaches deeper structures

symptoms: Chronic: Weight loss, swelling under jaw ('bottle jaw'), reduced milk production, anemia, poor/rough hair coat
Acute: Sudden death, abdominal pain/discomfort, jaundice, hemorrhage
cattle_diseases.transmission: Ingestion of metacercariae on vegetation near water sources
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Fecal egg counts, liver enzyme elevation, necropsy findings
healing_process: Improvement in 1-2 weeks after treatment
Complete recovery dependent on extent of liver damage
Severe liver damage is permanent
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good for early/moderate infections; poor with extensive liver damage

symptoms: Sudden death often without prior signs
Very high fever (106-108°F/41-42°C) if observed before death
Absence of blood clotting after death
cattle_diseases.transmission: Ingestion or inhalation of spores, biting flies
treatments: Penicillin or tetracyclines if caught very early
Usually fatal before treatment can be effective
healing_process: Rarely survive to undergo healing process
prevention: Proper disposal of carcasses (no necropsy, burial with quicklime)
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Very poor; usually fatal

cattle_diseases.transmission: Ingestion of contaminated feed containing ruminant proteins
healing_process: No recovery - progressive, fatal disease
prevention: Feed bans (no ruminant proteins in cattle feed)
Regulatory controls on slaughter and processing
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Fatal

treatments: Supportive care (fluids, nursing care for recumbent animals)
healing_process: Typical course of 3 days (hence "three-day sickness")
Most animals recover completely within 1 week
Milk production typically returns to normal within 2 weeks
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Generally good; mortality usually <1%

symptoms: Hard, painful swelling of the tongue
Weight loss due to inability to eat
cattle_diseases.transmission: Penetrating oral injuries with contaminated material
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, examination of exudate for "sulfur granules"
healing_process: Initial improvement in 2-3 days
Complete resolution in 1-3 weeks
prevention: Avoid coarse feeds that may cause oral abrasions
Proper pasture management to reduce sharp plant materials
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; poor if chronic and extensive

cattle_diseases.alternative_names: Grass tetany, Grass staggers, Lactation tetany
symptoms: Rapid progression to inability to rise/stand (recumbency)
Death often occurs within hours of first symptoms
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, serum magnesium levels, response to treatment
treatments: Emergency IV administration of magnesium solutions
Sedation may be required during treatment
healing_process: Rapid response to treatment (minutes to hours)
Complete recovery if treated promptly
May require ongoing nutritional management
prevention: Careful management during risk periods (early spring grazing)
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; poor once recumbent

symptoms: Stage 2: Sternal recumbency, S-shaped neck, cold extremities
Stage 3: Lateral recumbency, complete paralysis, unconsciousness
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, serum calcium levels, response to treatment
healing_process: Dramatic improvement within minutes of calcium administration
Standing within 1-2 hours in most cases
Complete recovery within 24 hours
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Excellent with prompt treatment; guarded in stage 3

healing_process: Clinical recovery in 7-14 days
Animals become lifelong carriers with periodic reactivation
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good for uncomplicated cases; poor if secondary pneumonia develops

cattle_diseases.alternative_names: Texas fever, Red water, Tick fever
symptoms: Neurological signs with B. bovis (circling, aggression)
healing_process: Initial response to treatment within 24-48 hours
Complete recovery in 2-4 weeks
Animals remain carriers
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Fair to good with early treatment; poor in advanced cases

symptoms: Sudden death often without prior signs
Hot, painful swelling that becomes cold and gaseous
Depression and complete loss of appetite
Dark, discolored areas of skin over affected muscles
cattle_diseases.transmission: Ingestion of bacterial spores from soil
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, bacterial culture, fluorescent antibody tests
treatments: Note: Treatment often ineffective due to rapid progression
healing_process: Extremely poor recovery rate even with treatment
Disease progression typically too rapid for effective intervention
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Very poor; usually fatal within 12-48 hours

symptoms: Weight loss despite normal appetite initially
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Intradermal tuberculin test, gamma interferon assay, PCR
healing_process: No recovery - progressive disease
prevention: Testing and removal of positive animals
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor; regulatory culling usually required

cattle_diseases.alternative_names: Hairy heel warts, Strawberry foot rot, Mortellaro disease
symptoms: Circular, raw, red, raised lesions typically at the heel bulb
Characteristic raised "strawberry-like" appearance with hair-like projections
Affected animals walk on toe to avoid bearing weight on heel
healing_process: Initial improvement in 1-2 days with proper treatment
Formation of scab within 7-10 days
Complete healing in 2-3 weeks
Tendency to recur if conditions favorable
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with treatment, but high recurrence rate

treatments: Treatment of entire group in outbreak situations
healing_process: Clinical improvement in 2-4 days with treatment
Complete recovery in 1-2 weeks
Intestinal damage may take 3-4 weeks to fully heal
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; guarded in severe cases

symptoms: Primarily affects calves 1-3 weeks of age
healing_process: Self-limiting disease in immunocompetent animals
Recovery in 10-14 days
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with supportive care; guarded in severely affected calves
cattle_diseases.zoonotic_potential: Yes - can cause diarrheal illness in humans

symptoms: Papules, pustules, and erosions on muzzle and oral mucosa
Lesions primarily around the mouth, nostrils, and lips
Occasional spread to teats and skin around hooves
cattle_diseases.transmission: Direct contact, contaminated feed/equipment, milking equipment
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, electron microscopy, PCR, virus isolation
treatments: Antibiotics only if secondary bacterial infection present
healing_process: Self-limiting disease in most cases
Recovery in 1-3 weeks
Lesions progress from papules to pustules to scabs which then heal
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Excellent; rarely fatal, primarily affects young cattle
cattle_diseases.zoonotic_potential: Yes - can cause lesions in humans (milker's nodules)

symptoms: Firm, circumscribed nodules (0.5-5 cm) in skin and subcutaneous tissue
Nodules may cover entire body but concentrate on head, neck, udder, and perineum
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, PCR, virus isolation, histopathology
healing_process: Acute phase lasts 4-14 days
Nodules may become necrotic and slough, leaving holes in hide
Recovery period of 4-6 weeks
Skin lesions may persist for several months
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Most cattle recover but with permanent skin damage; fatality rate 1-3%

cows_heifers: Prolonged calving interval at herd level

cattle_diseases.transmission: Sexual contact, contaminated semen or equipment
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Preputial scraping culture from bulls, PCR
treatments: No approved treatment for cattle in most countries
Rest period for cows allows most to clear infection within 3-5 months
healing_process: Self-limiting in females with sexual rest (3-5 months)
Bulls remain permanently infected
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor for infected bulls; good for females after sexual rest

cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Vaginal mucus agglutination test, preputial washings, PCR
treatments: Local treatment of bulls with antiseptic washes (limited efficacy)
healing_process: Cows typically develop immunity within 3-6 months
Bulls remain carriers unless treated
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good for individual animals; economic impact on herd productivity

healing_process: No recovery - persistent infection
Progressive disease in cattle that develop lymphosarcoma
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor once lymphosarcoma develops; fatal within weeks to months

symptoms: Lesions primarily on back, rump, neck, and face
Pain and pruritus (itching) in affected areas
cattle_diseases.transmission: Direct contact, biting insects, prolonged wetting
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, microscopic examination of crusts, bacterial culture
treatments: Removal of scabs and cleaning of lesions
healing_process: Initial response to treatment in 3-7 days
Complete healing in 2-4 weeks
Hair regrowth may take several months
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with treatment; poor if extensive lesions or chronic disease

cattle_diseases.alternative_names: Fog fever, Acute bovine pulmonary emphysema and edema (ABPEE)
cattle_diseases.transmission: Not contagious - associated with dietary change (typically moving to lush pasture)
treatments: Antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection
healing_process: Acute phase lasts 2-4 days
Survivors typically recover in 7-10 days
Lung damage may be permanent in severe cases
prevention: Feeding hay before turning out to new pasture
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Guarded to poor; mortality rate can be 30-50%

cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, virus isolation, serology, PCR
healing_process: Typical course of 3 days (hence "three-day sickness")
Recovery in 5-7 days in uncomplicated cases
Return to normal milk production within 2 weeks
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good; mortality usually low (<1%)

treatments: Antibiotics only for secondary bacterial infections
healing_process: Self-limiting; clinical signs for 3-7 days
Return to normal milk production within 2 weeks
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Excellent; rarely fatal though economically significant

cattle_diseases.causative_agents: Multifactorial - UV radiation, genetic predisposition, viral factors
symptoms: Small white plaque or pink mass on cornea, third eyelid, or eyelid
Ulceration and bleeding in advanced cases
healing_process: Depends on treatment method
Surgical sites typically heal in 2-3 weeks
Recurrence rate of 20-30%
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early intervention; poor for advanced metastatic disease

treatments: Supportive care (fluids, oxygen in severe cases)
healing_process: Uncomplicated cases resolve in 7-10 days
Pulmonary function may take 30-40 days to fully recover
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good for mild cases; guarded for severe cases

symptoms: Usually mild disease unless complicated by other pathogens
treatments: Antibiotics only for secondary bacterial infections
healing_process: Recovery in 5-7 days for uncomplicated cases
May predispose to bacterial pneumonia
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Excellent for uncomplicated cases; variable if secondary bacterial infection occurs

treatments: Eye patches to reduce light exposure
healing_process: Improvement within 3-5 days with treatment
Complete healing in 2-4 weeks
Severe cases may result in permanent scarring or blindness
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; guarded when ulceration is severe

cattle_diseases.causative_agents: Mannheimia haemolytica, Pasteurella multocida, Histophilus somni, Bovine respiratory syncytial virus (BRSV), Parainfluenza-3 virus (PI3)
symptoms: Nasal discharge (clear to thick and mucopurulent)
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, lung auscultation, PCR testing, bacterial culture
healing_process: Initial improvement in 24-48 hours with appropriate treatment
Full recovery within 7-14 days depending on severity
Lung scarring may occur in severe cases, reducing future performance
prevention: Stress reduction during transportation and handling
Isolation of new animals before introduction to herd
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with early treatment; guarded to poor in advanced cases

cattle_diseases.causative_agents: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) Types 1 and 2
symptoms: Persistently infected (PI) calves may appear stunted or normal
treatments: Anti-inflammatory drugs for fever and pain
healing_process: Acute cases: recovery in 2-3 weeks
Severe cases: may take 4-6 weeks for recovery
Persistently infected animals do not recover
prevention: Testing and removal of persistently infected animals
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Variable; good for mild cases, poor for mucosal disease form

symptoms: Vesicles (blisters) in mouth, on tongue, lips, teats, and between hooves
cattle_diseases.transmission: Direct contact, aerosol, fomites, vehicles, contaminated feed
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, ELISA, PCR, virus isolation
healing_process: Natural recovery in 2-3 weeks if no complications
Secondary infections may prolong recovery
prevention: Quarantine and/or culling of affected animals
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Generally not fatal in adults but causes severe production losses

cattle_diseases.causative_agents: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus agalactiae, E. coli, Klebsiella, Mycoplasma, and others
symptoms: Swollen, hot, and painful udder quarter(s)
Abnormal milk (watery, clots, flakes, pus, blood-tinged)
cattle_diseases.transmission: Environmental contamination, milking equipment, between cows during milking
cattle_diseases.diagnosis_methods: California Mastitis Test (CMT), somatic cell count, bacterial culture
treatments: Frequent milking or stripping of affected quarters
Supportive care (fluids, electrolytes) for severe cases
healing_process: Clinical improvement within 2-3 days with appropriate treatment
Complete elimination of infection may take 7-21 days depending on pathogen
Chronic cases may never fully recover, resulting in fibrosis and reduced production
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good for acute cases with early treatment; guarded for chronic infections

symptoms: Chronic, progressive weight loss despite normal appetite
healing_process: No recovery - progressive, fatal disease
May take years from infection to clinical signs
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Poor - eventually fatal once clinical signs appear

healing_process: Initial improvement in 1-3 days after treatment
Complete recovery in 2-3 weeks
Animals remain carriers for life
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Fair to good with early treatment; poor in advanced cases

symptoms: Reduced milk production with thick, yellow colostrum-like secretions
cattle_diseases.transmission: Contact with urine from infected animals, contaminated water
healing_process: Recovery from acute disease in 1-2 weeks with treatment
Some animals become chronic carriers
cattle_diseases.prognosis: Good with treatment for acute disease; abortion may still occur
